turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: We've always taken the position in Chicago that we have a right to make one group march in one street and another group march in another so they don't clench --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh, and like -- how can you regulate them like that if you can't regulate them?
You're going to let one have a better place that the other?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: No, we usually let the one that's there first march on that street.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has Chicago yet passed any -- has Chicago or the state yet passed any law?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean the kind of law that this Court has been admonishing must be passed in this field for years in narrowly drawn, nondiscriminatory statute acting on the assumption in the state does have a right to control marchers on its streets and demonstration.
Has it drawn one like that yet?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: The State Legislature has adopted a statute prohibiting residential marching.
The City --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- is that to all --

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- nondiscriminatory?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It has done that.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that -- to that extent, meets it seems that they are taking note of the fact that this Court in case after case have said, statutes must be narrowly drawn in this field to meet a particular situation hanging.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: And Mr. Justice Black, we --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm glad to hear that.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: We have amended our disorderly conduct ordinance to reflect this narrow construction of the State Supreme Court also.
Abraham Lincoln said 150 years ago that the world is -- has never had a good definition of the word liberty and that the American people just now are very much in want of one.
He said, “We all declare for liberty but when we use the same word, we do not all mean the same thing by it.”

And Professor Paul for in writing specifically on the topic of civil liberties said, “Not only to civil liberties vary in their quality but in many cases that is far from clear with which side the entrance of civil liberties are to be identified.”
Your Honors, for five and a half hours on a hot August day, petitioners exercised their right of free speech.
They call the mayor a snake.
They demanded that he fire the Superintendent of Schools.
They came across loud and clear as the record indicates they could be heard over a block away.
They had been in the immediate residential area for an hour and a half.
Many of the angry, threatening spectators were life long friends of the Daley family and residents of the community.
It had the police commander ordered them to disperse they could have at least deserved an equal right to be at 35th in Lowe.
When the commander explained his apprehensions of other riots in Mr. Gregory and asked for his cooperation in terminating the march, he refused.
He said he would march for an indefinite period of time.
He seemed determined that he would march until he was removed by the police or by the crowd.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Were they saying these things at the time they were arrested?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: No, Mr. -- no, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How long before that did they quit?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: They quit at 8:30 and they were arrested at 9:30.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood you just say a little while ago then that there was no violation of law prior to the order of the commander to disperse.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: That's our contention in this case Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.
Well, now what was the disorderly conduct if they were engaged in at the time this thing happened, not an hour before but on or about the time this thing happened?
What were they doing that was --

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Precisely in the language of the Illinois Supreme Court, a breach of the peace was imminent.
The police had protected them for as long as they could.
They asked them to desist.
They explain why they wanted them to desist and they refused.
Therein lays the city's contention of the disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did these marchers have in mind what the Supreme Court might say in this case?

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: In -- in the Winters' case, this Court pointed out that they are as chargeable --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I'm asking about the interpretation of your statute.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: In -- indeed Your Honor.
The legal answer is yes that they are as charged with subsequent judicial determinations as they are with knowledge of the law itself.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I -- I thought you said to Mr. Justice Stewart that there was no pre-warning that this would be the interpretation of the statute by the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: Oh, no.
No, I was answering Mr. Justice Stewart that no previous decisions --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's what I --

turn.speaker: raymond_f_simon
turn.label: Mr. Raymond F. Simon
turn.text: -- before the Supreme Court decision in the Gregory case had held that but we --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's right.
